content.question:
Half-Reaction
 Standard Reduction Potential, <math alttext="E naught in volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>(V</mtext><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="A g with a positive 1 charge aqueous plus one electron produce A g solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mtext>Ag(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="positive 0.80" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>0.80</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="P b with a positive 2 charge aqueous plus 2 electrons produce P b solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Pb</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mtext>Pb(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="negative 0.13" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.13</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="Z n with a positive 2 charge aqueous plus 2 electrons aqueous produce Z n solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mtext></mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mtext>Zn(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="negative 0.76" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.76</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

The cell potential for the standard galvanic cell shown above is <math alttext="positive 1.56 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>1.56</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. If <math alttext="The A g N O 3 aqueous, A g solid half-cell" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>AgNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mrow><mo>|</mo><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is replaced with <math alttext="1 molar P b, open parenthesis, N O 3, close parenthesis, 2 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Pb</mtext><mtext>(</mtext><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution and a <math alttext="P b" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Pb</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> electrode, which of the following describes what happens to the operation of the cell, and why?

choices.label: Nothing changes because galvanic cells that have a <math alttext="Z n solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> electrode have a constant cell potential, <math alttext="E naught sub cell" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>l</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, of <math alttext="positive 1.56 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>1.56</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The cell stops generating a voltage because the standard reduction potentials of <math alttext="P b with a positive 2 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Pb</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Z n with a positive 2 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> are both negative.

The cell potential decreases because the reduction of <math alttext="P b with a positive 2 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Pb</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> is less thermodynamically favorable than the reduction of <math alttext="A g with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The cell potential increases because twice as many electrons are transferred between <math alttext="P b with a positive 2 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Pb</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Z n" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> than between <math alttext="A g with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Z n" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Zn</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: The cell potential decreases because the reduction of <math alttext="P b with a positive 2 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Pb</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> is less thermodynamically favorable than the reduction of <math alttext="A g with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ag</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 2.F: Explain how modifications to an experimental procedure will alter results.
